messages: 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:15): Am I the only one who thinks that the existence of Ctrl+scroll wheel in browsers probably causes many more users to find websites mysteriously the wrong size than it actually helps anyone?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:15): you are not
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:22): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, it helps me
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:22): Well, it probably doesn't *hurt* anyone in this channel, because we all know the magic Ctrl+0 trick.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:23): But I constantly see people asking how to reset their browser to the right zoom level.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:23): I use zoom shortcuts too, but would it really hurt to have them less accessible?  Like Ctrl-Shift-mouse wheel or something?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:24): this is why Opera disables single key shortcuts by defaults - they are too easy to hit by accident
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:24): its easy to be using ctrl for something and hit the scroll wheel by accident
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:27): Oh, it does that for all single-key shortcuts?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:27): I recall it requires Shift-Esc or something for accesskeys, which always struck me as inconvenient.
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:27): theres an option that simply re-enables single key shortcuts, like z for back and x for forward
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (20:33): I remember when Opera had a single-key shortcut for turning images on and off, it was bloody annoying :)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:34): Oh, so we were talking about double-key shortcuts, not single-key.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:34): Backspace is an annoying shortcut.
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:35): I find it more annoying that my firefox doesn't have that shortcut
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:35): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 - strongly agreed, backspace is a very annoying shortcut.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:35): really wish I could disable that
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:36): have lost content too many times due to that shortcut
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:36): I've used backspace on a laptop before, when I didn't have a mouse with back/forward buttons.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:36): The back button on my current mouse hasn't worked for a long time, though, and I mostly just click the back button when I want to go back.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:36): should look into that.

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:36): e.g. you think you're focused in a text field, and want to delete characters you just typed, but it turns out the "document" has focus, and then backspace/delete goes back, and loses your textarea edits.
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:37): your browser doesn't remember the field contents?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:37): wishes he could patch is browsers to *not* treat backspace/delete as "go back" in navigation.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:38): Steve^ depends on if the page was the result of a form submit etc.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:38): then if you try to go forward, you get asked, do you want to resubmit? etc.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:38): = dataloss
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:38): or worse, AJAX hacks to edit content that don't recover from back/forward
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:39): Anyway, one of my first MediaWiki commits was removing an annoying shortcut.  https://bugzilla.wikimedia.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8203
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:40): apart from the AJAX wizardry, your browser doesn't account for form submit pages?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:40): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, well, if you use an open-source browser, you can!
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:41): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 - not without lots of work recompiling and merging with updates.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:41): Probably wouldn't have to do much work merging with updates, just recompiling.  It's unlikely those lines would get changed often.  But, yeah, just saying.
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:41): Maybe I'll just point out that Opera has none of these problems, without you patching the browser?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:42): might be simpler in the short-term
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:42): seems to me like shortcuts should be in a separate config file anyway
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:42): Yeah, every game out there lets you change all your shortcuts -- why not browsers too?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:42): I'd be fine even with a "defaults write com.apple.webkit ... " type solution (for webkit, firefox etc.)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:42): Opera has a handy keyboard shortcut editing dialog so you can disable backspace there if you want
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c - nice - thanks I'll check that out.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:43): (in Preferences/Advanced/Shortcuts)
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:43): hmm, Philip stealing my ideas!
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:43): So, <video> replaces flash on the ipad. What's going to replace PDFs?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:44): Who wants to replace PDFs?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:44): i.e, when are we going to able to print properly from the net?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:44): PDF is a standard format, why do you need to replace it?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:44): doesn't work on my phone
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:44): Just use a different implementation if you don't like Adobe's.
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:45): if its a matter of time for it to get to all devices, then that's probably ok
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:45): I assumed it was more of a royalty deal
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:45): or implementation problem
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:45): PDF can be implemented royalty-free.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:45): There's already lots of reader and writer implementations
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:45): Tons of programs support it.
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:45): does Android have one?
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (20:45): My phone has a pdf reader installed by default.
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (20:46): I've never used it though :p
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:46): thought HTML+CSS was supposed to replace the need for PDF. ;)
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:47): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, that's what you'd expect, but you can't print from the web - I can't do my CV in HTML
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:47): Steve^, why not?
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:47): it's ideal in that you can format exactly how you want and yet the browsers let you down
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:47): I've done a resume in HTML before.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:47): remembers helping to write some pretty damn good print (including print preview and size/image tweaking) in IE5/Mac ~ 10 years ago.
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (20:48): I write my CV in HTML and print it to a pdf...
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (20:48): Steve^ re: CV in HTML: http://microformats.org/wiki/hresume
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:48): I'm speaking from experience in trying to get something I know will print to 2 pages
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:50): ok, Opera printing a full-screen CV document: the right margin is about 3 inches wide
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:50): same as the bottom
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:51): ooo, chrome does a pretty good job
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:53): I dont' think I've tried printing my resume before, I just send it around as a link.  And it's all marked up with hresume. ^_^
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:54): I think the printing is more for myself than employers
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:54): I want to send a PDF around but Open Office is useless
3cd30a070a8cd420f1a52db2a8b12754 (20:55): looks like Chrome produces a good quality doc though, so I might try this in the future
